description: From Middle English *basshen, *basken, likely from Old Norse *baska (“to strike”), akin to Swedish basa (“to baste, whip, lash, flog”), Danish baske (“to beat, strike, cudgel”), German patschen (“to slap”)

examples: He got a bash on the head.

entries.meaning: (informal) A large party; a gala event.
examples: They had a big bash to celebrate their tenth anniversary.

entries.meaning: (UK, informal) An attempt at doing something.
examples: I'm not sure I'll be any good at this, but let me have a bash.
This was my first bash at macramé, so I'm quite pleased with how it's turned out.

verbs.description: bash (third-person singular simple present bashes, present participle bashing, simple past and past participle bashed)

examples: The thugs kept bashing the cowering victim.
If the engine won't start, bash it with this hammer.

entries.meaning: (informal) To collide; used with into or together.
examples: Don't bash into me with that shopping trolley.

description: From Middle English baschen, baissen. See abash.

verbs.description: bash (third-person singular simple present bashes, present participle bashing, simple past and past participle bashed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To abash; to disconcert or be disconcerted or put out of countenance.
